poem:
"Stages Unfolding"

In the shadow of curtain folds,
a tender revelation: a boy
spinning on a sheen of polished ice,
laughter caught in floodlight glow.

A keg of golden malt,
Pulp records spun with naught but glee,
the theatre - heartbeat of a hometown -
morphing an eager lad into a stripping vicar.

A stage of life,
woven as a play,
in silent conversations with the self.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The week in theatre: Starter for Ten; Uncle Vanya review – fingers on buzzers, and samovars James Graham, the playwright with the surest of political touches, was a captivating castaway last week on Desert Island Discs. He chose a keg of single malt and Pulp and revealed that as a 10-year-old he took to the ice rink – as a stripping vicar. He described the central importance of the theatre in his home town of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
